Hi, my name is Jennifer Muller. I am the learning lab supervisor, learning coach, and substitute PE teacher for the CCS online program. I graduated from the University of Minnesota with a degree in Family Social Science and later from Drexel University with my Teaching degree for grades K-6.

In 2012, I did my student teaching at the Crosslake Community School with the greatest mentor teacher, Beverly Loeffler. After teaching and living in Germany for 21 years, our family moved back home to Minnesota in 2018. I enjoy spending time with my family, being active, summer days on the lake, and reading.

I live with my husband and two daughters. Our third daughter is going to college in Germany, and we are very excited for her to come home for the summer in June. During this stay at home time, we are enjoying quality family time, finishing up construction, but looking forward to more social public events.

Wishing everyone good health, an awesome summer, and much laughter.

I’ve moved around a bit in the past few years with more moves to come, but I currently live just south of Westhope, ND, on an old farmstead - big red barn and all! I never dreamed of living in a tiny home, but I’m finding I really enjoy it!

I’ve been pretty busy keeping up with my roles as a learning coach and as a substitute rural mail carrier with the post office. But I’ve also been spending a fair amount of time this spring with my dogs, reading, ATVing, drawing, practicing piano, and learning new recipes.

Sending you all warm wishes for safety and peaceful minds in these times of uncertainty, and looking forward to working with you!

Hello! I am Clare Thompson. I teach middle school online at CCS with a community of amazing, supportive coworkers. I am so proud to be a part of the team!

The individualized help and pacing that I can give a student is much greater than what I can give in the typical classroom approach. Hi! My name is Beverly Loeffler, and I am the Title I teacher for the K-8 seat based program. That means I meet with students who need a little extra support with math and reading. I am also the district assessment coordinator (testing).

This was day two of distance learning for my family. Wow, has it been going fast for me and I have been learning a lot! Some things my family has done to make things smoother is to have a schedule posted on our refrigerator.

If we are on a live meeting, we go to a quiet spot. We have also been remembering to take a break, especially when we do not understand something. I also have a check-out sheet for each of my three boys to make sure they have done each subject every day.

I was so excited to see my students today on our Google meetings. Everyone seemed to be doing well. Keep up the great work everyone.

Hi! I'm Stephanie Schubert, and I'm a learning coach and social studies teacher at CCS-Online.

I love my home work space, and lately I've enjoyed sharing a "school room" with my three kids and our labradoodle. Hi! I'm Toni LeBlanc, mom of three CCS seat-based students and paraprofessional/education assistant at CCS... and yes, the "distance learning" struggle is real!

So far, my findings are organization and setting up a schedule are super important. Communication and allowing for grace are even more important. I mostly work from my dining room table, these days, so I am able to be there, as needed, for all of my kids, my own kids and my school kids.

I also set up a pop-up office in our unfinished basement. This is the "mom is working, ask dad" office, for when my undivided attention is needed.

So far, so good. It's definitely a balance, but all of life is a balance.

If you want to do some preparing for the distance learning that starts on Monday, you and your family could start thinking about your students’ work stations at home.

Stacy Bender, director of the online program, likes to have a standing station as her main desk area. This allows her to keep moving during the day and to stretch frequently. She takes her phone calls or participates in online meetings at a chair not pictured.

Students may need a wider configuration than this as they may need a book on one side and a notebook on the other, but this shows a good start to what you may like. Some families may want all of their student around a dining room table. Be willing to change as you see your students’ needs develop.

It is always a good idea for students to be in common rooms as opposed to their bedrooms in order to promote accountability and internet safety.

High school students from the online program attended the Career Fair at Central Lakes College today. We are grateful for programs like Bridges Career Academies and Workplace Connection who provide opportunities like this for our students!

Our online program serves students from the entire state of Minnesota in grades 5-12 at no cost because we are a public option as an approved online provider. We can serve students full-time as they work toward their high school diploma. We also provide supplemental online classes to students enrolled in other Minnesota schools who need to take an online class for a variety of reasons to replace a class at their enrolling district.

Our program started in August 2014 with 13 students and now enrolls 180 full-time students and more than 50 supplemental students. Go to our website (crosslakekids.org) or call Molly (218-537-3628) for more information.

We are so proud of our January high school graduates! Many of them will return to participate in our May ceremony.

Some students graduated early while others had life get in the way in other years that then required them to need a little extra time to finish their credit requirements for graduation. Either way, we are proud of them and are grateful to have been part of the journey!

Did you know that Minnesota students are eligible for public (free) education until they turn 21 years of age? If you know someone between the ages of 18 and 21 whose life interrupted their education, encourage them to return to high school and finish. There are many options available, and we would love to help them find the right one!

More information is available on our website: crosslakekids.org

Thanks to a grant from Crow Wing Energized, our students have water bottles to use with our building hydration stations! Our prekindergarten students received their bottles yesterday.

We are so grateful for this as we look to decrease our use of plastic. The hydration stations keep track of how many plastic bottles have been saved because of our use of them.

This also helps our students be healthy by increasing their daily water intake. Our Wellness Committee is grateful for this combination of wellness and environmental education opportunity.

Heads up: Teachers will send them home with students periodically to have parents wash them. Please be sure to send them back.
